INTRODUCTION 1.1 The education system in Russia has been characterized by high enrollment in primary and secondary education, impressive levels of literacy, equitable access for girls and excellent academic achievements particularly in mathematics and natural sciences. However, in the centrally planned economy, there was an inefficient use of resources, overstaffing and high unit costs, together with duplication and fragmented programs. There were few opportunities for non-university, post-secondary education. The system had weak incentives for teaching independent enquiry, critical thinking, or problem solving. 1.2 As early as 1985, and increasingly after 1990, it was recognized in Russia that reform of education was needed to develop informed citizens capable of participating in a democratic society as well as to give workers more marketable skills. In the intervening years much has been accomplished to reorient the system by transferring a number of administrative and fiscal responsibilities from the center to the regions and by granting greater freedom and incentives to regions to increase efficiency, change the content of curricula, promote pedagogic initiatives and achieve greater responsiveness to the demands of the evolving labor market. 1.3 If Russia is to restore economic growth and achieve competitiveness in an international market, it is essential that the education system be strengthened to improve the quality of teaching and to reorient management structures to take into account the new responsibilities of federal and regional authorities for decision making and finance in the education sector. The legacy of centralized control, rigidity and lack of accountability continue to constrain efforts at innovation and greater efficiency and to hamper local and private initiatives in education. The challenge will be to reorient the education system to encompass the demands of a new economic system while retaining the considerable strengths and achievements of the past in a period of severe fiscal constraint. A. Sector Description 1.4 Structure: Education in Russia consists of 9 years of compulsory basic education (7-15 year olds). Three types of secondary education exist: (a) general secondary education which has little or no vocational content and is the preparation for entering higher education and other types of education; (b) vocational education (2-3 years) geared to the preparation of skilled workers and trades; and (c) secondary specialized education (2-4 years depending on the point of entry) offering a more theoretical curriculum along with training in more sophisticated technical skills. Higher education consists of 535 public institutions: 129 universities, 28 academies, and 378 colleges. In addition there are 193 non-public higher education institutions (141 are licensed institutions). In 1992, the State Committee for Higher Education (SCHE) suggested that Higher Education Institutions (HEIs) introduce a multilevel structure for higher education. It divides the system into three layers consisting of a four year Bachelors program, a five year professional certificate program, and a six year Master's program. Approximately 20 percent of institutions have adopted this structure. This makes the length of these institutions' degree programs roughly comparable to OECD systems, while fostering flexibility and greater efficiencies. In August 1996, the Ministry of Education and the SCHE were amalgamated into one Ministry of General and Professional Education (MGPE).
 2 Chapter I 1.5 Enrollments: Russian education has traditionally had an enrollment of virtually 100 percent of children of compulsory school age. After completing compulsory education, over 50 percent of school children continue their education in general secondary schools, approximately 30 percent in vocational schools, and approximately 20 percent in technical secondary schools. Total enrollment has declined since the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991, by 9 percent in secondary technical schools, 7 percent in vocational schools, and 5 percent in higher education. Only in compulsory education has the number of students increased. At the same time the size of the age cohort and the demand for higher education, especially in skills required for new labor markets, are on the increase. If these trends continue they will change the future demand for schooling and the need for teachers and facilities. 1.6 Basic indicators: Russia's education indicators compare favorably with OECD countries in many respects. Participation and access have been high at the preschool and compulsory levels. Female participation in higher education is equal to that of males. Higher education has a lower participation rate than the OECD average. Repetition and dropout have been traditionally almost non-existent. Average levels of achievement in mathematics and natural sciences are higher than in many OECD countries. A large proportion of students are in higher-cost vocational and technical schools (technikums) that are training for skills no longer relevant for the economy. Student/teacher ratios are low relative to OECD standards at all levels. 1.7 Teachers: There are almost six million teachers in the education system. Declines in student enrollment in some sub-sectors and the rise in demand for new skills in others have implications for future teacher supply, skill-mix, and deployment. Low student/teacher ratios are evident at all levels of education. They are caused by the prevalence of labor intensive, face-to-face, oral approaches to teaching and assessment. Lecture and note-taking predominate. Team-teaching and small group discussions are rare. Library resources and the use of independent source materials are a fraction of the norm elsewhere. Examinations and assessments tend to be oral. This type of pedagogy is not efficient and points to a need to invest in new teaching methods and materials to make the pedagogical process more efficient and less labor-intensive. Teacher salaries have lagged behind other sectors. The average teacher salary was 81 percent of the average industrial wage in 1980; by 1994 it had fallen to 66 percent. The salary of a professor fell from 219 percent of industrial wage in 1987 to 62 percent in July of 1993. As a result the better teachers and those with skills in high demand (foreign languages, economics, survey research) are leaving the profession. However, despite salary instability, overall employment in compulsory and higher education appears to have increased since 1991. 1.8 Management: During the Soviet regime, control by distant Moscow-based structures, segmented sectoral ownership, norm-based financing, and the lack of adequate school based authority characterized education management. Much change has occurred in the structure of educational governance over the last three years. However, the sources of authority have been many, overlapping, and of varying legitimacy. Regional and district authorities are now responsible for financing primary and secondary education. In the past, federal authorities were responsible for providing the entire curriculum, pedagogical materials and equipment, and their associated expenses. With the recent establishment of federal, regional and school-defined curricula, local authorities are assuming new responsibilities and expenditures in this area as well as for teacher supervision and in-service training, maintenance, and budget management. All vocational and some technical schools are financed by the MGPE; some other technical schools are financed by the relevant sectoral ministries. In an effort to adapt to emerging labor markets, the regional role in the finance and management of vocational schools is expected to increase.
 Russian Federation: Education Innovation Project Page 3 1.9 The MGPE and 21 different federal ministries finance and manage institutions of higher education. At the same time, regional authorities are beginning partially to finance local higher education institutions to meet the needs of regional industries, labor markets, and tax payers. The question of which level of public authority should manage higher education is determined by the federal law on higher and post graduate profession education. Entrance examinations to higher education are designed and administered differently (mostly oral with no standardization) by each of the roughly nine departments in each of the 535 higher education institutions scattered across the country. Education Research is under the authority of the MGPE and the Russian Academy of Education. 1.10 Expenditure: Formal spending in Russia for social protection-' (9% of GDP) is significantly lower than expenditure levels in Eastern Europe (averaging around 14 % of GDP), but higher than in most countries at the comparable GDP per capita level. Russia devoted 7 percent of GDP to education in the early 1970s. This declined to 3.8 percent in 1991, 3.4 percent in 1992, rose to 4.4 percent in 1994, and then declined again to 3.4 percent in 1995. Education expenditure has been broadly protected during the transition period although GDP share is below many OECD countries. Because GDP has declined precipitously since 1991, real per student spending has declined. These declines were unevenly spread across the system, higher for pre-school and compulsory education, lower for specialized secondary and higher education. Moreover, differences in per pupil spending between the 89 regions of the Russian Federation are increasing. In 1994, higher education accounted for 23% of total public educational expenditures which was low compared to some OECD countries. Compulsory education at 50 percent was low, especially given that only 38 percent was devoted to general education while 12 percent was allocated to vocational education. Salary expenditures are financed with increasing difficulty while non- salary items including textbooks, equipment, capital investments and repairs have received lower priority B. Key Issues of Transition 1.11 Lessons from international research and experience on effective school systems underline the importance of relevant curricula and teaching and learning materials, flexible teaching approaches that develop critical thinking and problem solving, school based autonomy and accountability in resource management and decision making. In the past, ideology and isolation kept the Russian education system outside these trends. Under central planning, the Russian education system operated without adequate incentives to encourage accountability for costs and managerial efficiency. Curricula emphasized uniformity. Governance structures catered to distant, uncoordinated federal ministries rather than to local labor markets and needs. There are different requirements for managing an education system to produce graduates with the type of skills to cater to the needs of a market economy and a democratic civic culture. Government has launched an ambitious reform program to respond to these new requirements. Financial instability and decline during the transition coupled with the legacy of past assumptions, structures, incentives, and attitudes have slowed on-going attempts at reform. Issues central to reform of education in Russia are summarized below. 1.12 Governance: It is envisaged that the recent changes in the structure of the MGPE will encourage the development of education sector policy and strategy in Russia and will create a national mechanism to lead and coordinate more in-depth technical analysis, comprehensive strategic planning, and broad 1/ Including Social Insurance (pensions, unemployment benefits), family allowances and social assistance programs but not subsidized housing and utilities.
 4 Chapter I public discussion and consensus for the reform of both compulsory and post-compulsory education. 1.13 Finance: The fiscal base of education is threatened because of the decline in public revenues for education which has resulted in a steep reduction in per-student expenditures by educational level since 1991 together with an increase in costs, especially energy costs. The sector has coped with these simultaneous expenditure decline and price increases by introducing guaranteed (protected) funding items: wages, stipends, food, and utilities. Expenditures on items such as textbooks, equipment, capital investments and repairs have received lower priority. Shortfalls in budgets have led to severe problems with physical resources and school buildings are often inadequately heated and maintained. Further reductions in expenditures on non-salary items would weaken educational effectiveness and diminish quality. Financial shortages in the education sector have not yet resulted in major improvements in efficiency. Student/teacher ratios remain low due to the labor-intensive, oral approaches to organizing instruction and assessmenta'. 1.14 Equity: The emphasis on educational decentralization and diversity is creating greater inequities. There are growing discrepancies in per pupil expenditures in compulsory education across and within the 89 regions in Russia. The existing system of education finance does not have explicit mechanisms for compensatory funding of educational spending and redistribution of budget revenues between regions with different fiscal bases. Consequently, variation in the access to good quality education is increasing. 1.15 Curicula and teaching methods are not yet fully responsive to the developing market economy where a premium is placed on problem-solving, occupational flexibility, innovation and creativity in teaching and learning and active participation in democracy. Incentives for teachers and managers to learn new pedagogical or management skills are absent and this in turn encourages the perpetuation of the rigid, hierarchical and inefficient system. However, in recent years there have been adjustments in curricula accompanied by attempts to introduce choice in compulsory education. In short, there is a growing internal potential for change in the education system which is hampered by a severe shortage of funding for the development of curricular innovations and their dissemination. 1.16 Teachers As has been already noted, teachers have suffered badly in the transition by having their salaries devalued and frequently paid several months in arrears while other job benefits (e.g.housing) are also disappearing. In spite of notable loyalty and commitment to their chosen vocation, it is evident that teachers are becoming increasingly demoralized. There is also concern about the quality of teacher training which often permits entry to those with a low level of educational attainment and fails to preserve professional standards through adequate retraining policies. 1.17 Examinations: As elsewhere, examinations in Russia strongly influence what is taught in schools and, to a large extent, determine the opportunity for further study and employment. The current mechanism for selection to higher education is inefficient and unfair. Entrance examinations are administered differently by each department in each of 535 institutions scattered across the country. Since there are about nine different departments in each higher education institution, there are in effect over 5000 different entrance examinations. Students are required to appear in person. In general, examinations in all institutions are administered at about the same time thus preventing candidates from 2/ Teacher-student ratios vary from 1:8 to 1:16 for the primary and secondary education sectors and average 1:10 for higher education.

Students have no guarantee that the level of difficulty of their test is equivalent to any other test in the same field or whether scoring criteria are comparable. Tests are designed by isolated tradition-bound faculty and departments which may have little understanding of the new knowledge and skill requirements of emerging labor markets. In a market economy, the pressure to enter higher education will increase, particularly in fields of high demand. In these circumstances, the need for an efficient, high quality, and fair method of selection to higher education will increase. 1.18 Educational Materials: A survey in schools which was carried out as part of project preparation reveals problems of supply, "age" and content of books. The implication of the survey is that over the next one to two years, textbooks will have to be replaced on a mass scale throughout the Russian Federation(RF) rather than at the normal rate of 25 % per annum. The absence of competition and of information hampers the development of new textbook content to meet new curriculum objectives and to support economic and social reform. The current estimated need for the publication of new textbooks, new editions and reprints of existing textbooks is difficult to estimate. However from existing data on books supplied through the MOE in former years and the under-funding of the system since 1993 there is now an estimated need for up to 400 million textbooks if the system is to be supplied to the specified level. At current prices this would cost upwards of $500 million equivalent. There remains a lack of clarity between various levels of government (and the schools) on textbook funding. In addition there is, in some cases, a separation of the final funding agencies (the oblasts) from control over contractual arrangements with the publishers and distributors. Placing orders through the MGPE, whether or not against the Ministry of Finance (MOF) debits, is costly and inefficient. Over 80 % of textbook production is still handled by the State monopoly publisher, Prosvescheniyie. There is a resulting inadequacy of choice and sometimes of quality of books in the school system. The continuance of this monopoly, in part dictated by the sheer size of the market and the working capital needs implied, is an obstacle to the development of a full market-oriented system. These factors discourage the further development of a potentially healthy private sector educational publishing industry. The current financing gap for textbooks is only marginally assisted by emergency funds from the MOF (for the poorer regions) and is interconnected with the MGPE's wish to reduce past indebtedness. C. Higher Education Sector 1.19 The Higher Education sector is under pressure because of the general economic situation, the reduction in federal budget financing and the need to modernize the curricular content and teaching methods of HEIs. Important indications of efforts to adjust to the changing needs of the general public for education and the needs of employers for human resources are changes in distribution of admissions and graduations by areas of specialization, increase in the number of new private colleges which provide training in the most wanted areas, changes in standards and the content of education. Some changes occurred in the system of governance and management of HEIs, reflected in the consolidation of the central structure of higher education management, the increase of academic freedom, and the introduction of the system of election of rectors. The system responded to reduced federal budget funding by drawing increasingly on the extra-budgetary and local budget sources. However, the reports on the Governance, Management and Funding of Higher Education which were completed as part of the project preparation process, demonstrate that the sector continues to suffer from a lack of clearly defined responsibilities between governing agencies together with an incomplete legal framework, insufficient transparency in the allocation and use of public funding and a need to modernize Higher Education course content and

Government Objectives and Strategy 1.20 The Government is committed to strengthening the education system to ensure that all children have access to high quality education so that each will have the opportunity to participate fully in and contribute to Russia's economic and social development. Achieving this objective requires an education system that is more flexible, more responsive to market signals, and more efficient in its use of resources than at present. The strategy for education is embodied in the 1992 Education Law and the 1993 Federal Program for Educational Development. The 1992 legislation emphasized curricular diversity, decentralized finance and management of compulsory education to the regions; and diversified sources of education finance including the legalization of private schools and institutions. The main intention of the 1993 federal education reform were to: * ensure implementation of the legal and regulatory enactments to make the 1992 education law effective; * develop regional capacity to finance and manage the education system; i adapt curricular content and pedagogy to respond to the needs of the individual, society, and emerging local labor markets; e diversify the types of educational institutions and sources of finance, especially private sources, in particular user charges in higher education and private sector participation at all levels; and * develop mechanisms to monitor the quality of educational inputs and outputs and to enforce educational standards, in particular the establishment of a Federal Testing and Assessment Center and development of Education Statistical Indicators to set national standards for educational inputs and performance, assess students/graduates learning achievement and skills, license teachers, and accredit and evaluate institutions and programs. 1.21 Since 1993, considerable progress has been made. A gradual decentralization of governance and management functions has been underway. New types of education are emerging; elements of new funding principles are being discussed. Renewal of the content of education is accelerating. Work has been started to revise minimum standards for compulsory education. Direct ministerial administrative control of the education system is declining. Institutional autonomy is increasing in areas of curriculum development, selection of teaching methods, and budget management. 1.22 In August 1996, there was a reorganization of the Government in which the former State Committee for Higher Education was combined with the former Ministry of Education into the new MGPE. This reorganization will mean that policy making for the education sector will be unified and strengthened. A Deputy Minister with special responsibility for the provision of textbooks and other educational materials on a federal level was appointed. 1.23 Also in August, 1996, the Government introduced a new law on Higher and Post-Graduate Education which clarified some ownership rights, and provided for tax-free and freehold use of land by
 Russian Federation: Education Innovation Project Page 7 HEIs. User fees for Higher Education are permitted for up to 25 % of students in public HEIs. Selection criteria for these students are different from those who do not pay for tuition. The most capable students theoretically can be enrolled in programs financed by public funding and so an implicit subsidy for lower income students is in place. 1.24 However, the lack of clarity about federal, regional and sub regional roles together with the diffusion of responsibilities between federal and local authorities are weakening the capacity to drive initiatives forward. Areas requiring continuing further reform are: * The financing system will need to be reformed for all levels of education, to ensure transparency, sustainability, responsiveness to changing student demands and enhanced competition among both old and new educational institutions. * Governance capacity at all levels will need to be strengthened by the introduction of measures to consolidate the education system and to preserve consistency. Policy making capacity should be supported through the development of educational statistics and indicators and through the promotion of transparent financing systems. Both of these measures will lead to greater public accountability. * It will be necessary to develop the accountability of compulsory education at local levels, including choice of curricula and educational materials. Work has been started to revise minimum standards for compulsory education. However, lack of funding has impeded progress in this area. There are still no approved policy guidelines to increase authority for regional governments for curriculum and choice of textbooks. * The most important objectives for Vocational and Higher Education are improved quality, greater flexibility, more involvement of regional governments and the reduction of administrative over head costs. It is also essential to integrate better research with education. The most capable students theoretically can be enrolled in programs financed by public funding and so an implicit subsidy for lower income students is in place. However, there is still no system of student loans or special supplements for low income students. Achieving these objectives will involve considerable restructuring and consolidation over a long period of time. 1.25 The proposed project, through its focus on the promotion of efficiencies in the teaching of social sciences in participating HEIs and on the revision of minimum standards for compulsory education together with the development a national program of textbook publishing reform, would constitute a strategic first step on the part of the Bank to support key reforms in the sector.

Bank Strategy 2.1 The objectives of the proposed Education Innovation Project (EIP) are consistent with the current Country Assistance Strategy for Russia (October 1996) and with the framework of action envisaged for the education sector in the Social Sector Strategy Note which would be to promote the: (a) clarification of responsibilities for policy development and implementation at various levels of federal and regional government; (b) development of financing mechanisms,like capitation, which would relieve underfunding in poorer regions and in non-salary expenditures, and help to link content of education more closely to student needs; (c) development of curricula, teacher training, career counselling, learning materials and other support systems more in line with the needs of the market economy and a democratic society; and (d) consolidation of facilities in higher education through the establishment of demand driven mechanisms. Meeting these reform objectives will require assistance to: (i) strengthen policy making and strategic planning at the federal level and (ii) to stabilize education finance, rationalize expenditure allocation, support new knowledge and skill development, and rationalize institutional structures and functions at the regional, district, and municipal levels. 2.2 The broad objective of education lending to Russia is to support Government efforts to: (a) maintain essential service levels, (b) increase the efficiency and equity of service delivery, (c) develop appropriate knowledge and skills critical for economic transition and social development, and (d) ensure the financial sustainability of the education system. 2.3 There are currently three projects with education and training components in the lending program that support these objectives. The Management and Financial Training (Ln. 3824-Ru.) (MFT) and the Employment Services and Social Protection (Ln. 8822-Ru.) (ESSP) projects address the development of human capital in Russia and emphasize adult training in short-cycle courses, where labor market needs could be readily identified. The MFT Project introduced the concept of demand-led training through the creation of the National Training Foundation (NTF) to define training strategies, identify priorities, and allocate training funds on a competitive basis. The third project, the Community Social Infrastructure Project (Ln. 4009-Ru.) (CSIP), which was approved by the Board in April 1996, addresses urgent social expenditure issues including education. It includes compulsory schools as a high priority for project finance and focuses on the need to rehabilitate and improve school facilities. It is a pilot project in two regions, with the expectation of eventual replication on a wider basis through further Bank lending projects or Government financing. 2.4 These three projects reflect the alternative approaches to project design the Bank is pursuing in social sector lending in Russia. These include: (a) institution building projects, (b) demonstration projects
 Russian Federation: Education Innovation Project Page 9 at the regional level, and (c) development of federal/local systems of financial transfers. The ESSP and MFT projects are institution building activities, although they both directly deliver programs and services too. Both of these projects will provide practical experience on what kinds of institutional structures and implementation arrangements work in Russia. The proposed Education Innovation Project would build directly on the experience of the MFT by utilizing the National Training Foundation as an organization to administer this project. The CSIP is a replicable, demonstration type activity and will provide an information base on approaches to improving services at the regional level. 2.5 The Education Innovation Project would be the first Bank financed project devoted exclusively to the education sector and will build upon the knowledge and experience gained in the previous Bank financed social sector projects in Russia. It constitutes a limited first step in revitalizing the education sector through the creation of an Innovation Fund (IF) to reform the teaching of social sciences and through the reform of the current textbook publishing system. B. Lessons from Experience 2.6 Past Bank experience indicates that effective implementation and longer-term sustainability of education projects depend strongly on the improvement of educational management at all governance levels as well as on the establishment of effective systems to manage sector and school level information, project monitoring information, and procurement and delivery activities. In the Europe and Central Asia (ECA) Region, projects in Hungary and Romania address many of the same issues and objectives as the proposed Project and offer lessons for project design in the transition economies. 2.7 Higher Education Innovation Fund: The Bank has considerable experience in the use of innovation type funds within higher education projects in Hungary, Indonesia, Tunisia, Brazil, Argentina. Generic experience with funds indicates the importance of: (a) careful phasing to match the pace and scale of the project; (b) building management capability; (c) building ownership and commitment through beneficiary participation in the design of the project; (d) flexibility to respond to change at federal and local level. One lesson of both Bank and European Union Education projects in Central and Eastern Europe which is particularly relevant to the present project is that incentives, rather than direct control, are the key to reform. Core budget funding, to be distributed to higher education institutions under an objective and transparent system, encourages responsiveness to the changing market demand and provides an ongoing incentive for efficiency improvement. 2.8 The Hungary Human Resources Project (Ln. 3313-HU, FY91) provided discretionary investment funding to individual institutions through three competitive rounds between competing Higher Education Institutes and launched a large number of new educational programs, including specific curricula and changed teaching methods. However, the impact of the project was weakened through fragmentation of much of the funding across institutions, resulting in small funding amounts and limited impact. In addition, there was insufficient protection for preserving the integrity of the peer review process for evaluating funding proposals. Guidelines relating to conflicts of interest were not well developed or monitored nor were evaluation procedures designed to discourage wholesale reallocation of funding recommendations, with the result that peer review had too little impact on decision making. These issues have been addressed in the design of the procedures in the proposed Innovation Fund where the size of the grants would be of sufficient magnitude to act as a catalyst to some reform and where the design of the eligibility criteria and conditions of award, will be the subject of ongoing scrutiny by Expert
 Page 10 Chapter II Committees comprising at least one international expert as well as a broad range of Russian expertise. 2.9 School Textbook Reform Component: The textbook component of the Romania Education project (Ln. 3724-RO, FY93) has similar broad objectives to the textbook component in this proposed project, e.g. to reform textbook quality and to encourage private publishers to compete for the development of new textbooks. The project encountered some initial problems related to the existing monopoly of state publishers; the problem was addressed by privatizing state publishers and then allowing them to compete for contracts on the same level as other private publishers which is a feature of this proposed project 2.10 There are also several generic lessons from implementing Bank financed projects in Russia. These include the importance of: (a) strong Government ownership; (b) consistent counterparts with authority for preparation; (c) inter-ministerial coordination; (d) including local consultants and institutions in all stages of project preparation; (e) setting up Project Implementation Units (PIUs) at an early stage with experienced advisors to facilitate efficient project management; and (f) early detailed attention to procurement and other implementation issues. 2.11 The proposed Project has closely followed each of the above generic lessons: (a) the Government established a Working Group as the Bank's counterpart in project preparation; (b) the preparation process has benefited from the same Government officials working as counterparts with the Bank and also from the same team of experts working for the Bank in Russia; (c) the Working Group has been chaired by the Ministry of Economy (MOE) and has had representatives from the MGPE and the MOF as well as from potential beneficiaries; (d) preparation of this project to date has been highly participatory and the fmal stages of project design were agreed in a workshop format where all counterparts and potential beneficiaries were present; and (e) recent experience with the County Portfolio Performance Review (CPPR) has been taken into account, specifically the lessons relating the need to strengthen institutional capacity to manage projects. The Government has advised that the NTF would administer the project. The project would therefore benefit from the NTF's experience with the Bank's procedures, including handling of procurement and disbursement.

Project Background 3.1 Building on the dialogue of the last few years, and on previous Bank experience with educational projects, the World Bank team, together with Russian colleagues developed a project which would impose modest elements of reform and serve as the basis for future lending in the sector. The proposed project would pilot reforms and would include a Higher Education component with a demand responsive emphasis on improving social science teaching 3' through the creation of an Innovation Fund, and a School Textbook Reform component which would support better quality and choice of textbooks. The rationale for including these two components is that the Government of Russia (GOR) has consistently requested support in these areas over several years of dialogue with the Bank and during two workshops and these components would represent a first step on which future lending operations could be built. B. Social sciences teaching, as is currently understood in OECD economies, is in urgent need of improvement and development, reflecting its absence in former times. It was recognized that these disciplines need a great deal of development in qualitative terms. They would be complementary to each other and mutually supportive. Each of the three windows would support sub-projects which would have a different focus and target group: Window I focuses on sub-projects to improve the teaching of social sciences linked to improved governance and efficiency of management in universities which major in teaching in these subjects; Window 2 focuses on sub-projects to improve governance and efficiency of management and is available to selected HEIs; and Window 3 focuses on sub-projects to improve academic linkages. Window 1: Social Science Institutions Capacity Building. This Window would support Social Science Development Schemes (SSDSs) by partially repayable grants allocated on a competitive selection basis for improvements in the teaching of social sciences linked to reform of governance and management at the institutional level. This Window would support Structural Reform Schemes (SRSs) by partially repayable grants allocated on a competitive selection basis for governance reform efforts. BENEFITS AND RISKS Benefits 6.1 The proposed project is designed to improve the quality, quantity, governance and efficiency of Russian education. 6.2 With respect to Higher Education the project will: * Enhance quality through incentives designed to make it comparable with international education in social sciences; * Increase quantity by increasing the number of appropriately trained social scientists through project investment in facilities, equipment, libraries and software; * Improve governance through the development and use of instruments that facilitate transparent and accountable management of Higher Education; and * Encourage efficiency through better use of available resources and through an incentive scheme for the preparation of graduates. 6.3 The School Textbook Reform component will: * Enhance quality through the further development of nationally established educational standards and tests, the encouragement of more relevant and better quality textbooks; * Increase quantity and efficiency through better information systems which will permit choice and timely ordering of school textbooks. * Increase significantly the role of the private sector in the supply of new educational titles. 6.4 The Pilot Textbook Procurement Fund will contribute towards: * overcoming barriers to entry and encouraging more competitive selection of textbooks * the demonopolization of the textbook publishing industry; * the creation of a sustainable system of funding for textbook supply for secondary education 6.5 There will be savings in educational costs as a result of: * more efficient use of resources in HEIs; * incentives for more transparent management and accounting practices within HEIs; * introduction of competition into textbook production. 6.6 There will be some direct cost-recovery from the HEIs but it will be less than complete. It is
 Page 34 Chapter VI anticipated that some of the HEI cost-savings will permit some overdue maintenance of HEIs. Any cost- savings in the supply of textbooks could have a direct impact on local budgets. 6.7 Although the IF will provide only a modest amount of support towards reform, experience elsewhere has shown that the effects of similar mechanisms provide a positive model for change which may be taken up by non-participating institutions which recognize the benefit of such an approach. This demonstration effect is an important feature of the sustainability of innovative approaches such as the IF. This component would also provide better and more accurate information on individual educational institutions which would benefit the next operations in the sector. 6.8 Increased efficiency is expected to lead to savings in expenditure on higher education, increased numbers of graduates in social sciences and improved quality of graduates. However, it is not feasible to calculate economic rates of return to these expenditures. In part this is because in such a pilot project it is extremely difficult to predict the precise outcomes. Second, the scarcity of graduates with training in modem economics and finance has been so acute in Russia in recent years that their current salary levels would probably exaggerate the apparent economic returns from the project. Third, while there is no doubt that the availability of textbooks is a critical element in the educational effectiveness of schools, there is no information that can be used to estimate the economic impact of this improved effectiveness. 6.9 Without this project, Higher Education in Russia would continue to suffer from a shortage of graduates in economics and other social sciences disciplines and would have to rely on more costly solutions to the need for well trained graduates in these disciplines. Similarly, without the initiatives which will be piloted in the School Textbook Reform component and without the Pilot Textbook Procurement Fund, the spread of new learning materials and the reform of the textbook publishing industry would be delayed. Risks 6.10 It is difficult to be certain of the eventual demand for the Innovation Fund. Since participating HEIs will have to make some repayments, there may be reluctance on the part of some of the most deserving HEIs to apply for grants. This might result in under use of the funds, or their use only by institutions which rely heavily on fee-paying students. Since, even with some cost-recovery, there will be some implicit subsidies, this could mean that the project was being inequitable. The participatory nature of project preparation, with sustained involvement of individuals representing a geographically and structurally diverse set of institutions, suggests that this risk is small. However, a further related risk that high rates of repayment would provide incentives for participating HEIs to engage in dubious commercial activities in order to repay the grants will also be taken into consideration. There will be careful monitoring of these potential risks, and the project design offers considerable flexibility to alter the incentives for application and/or condition of awards if the initial outcomes suggest that this would be desirable. It is also possible that HEIs will not continue with courses once the grants to initiate them have been fully used. Since the project will finance start-up rather than recurrent costs, this risk seems to be small. The cost recovery system whereby competing Higher Education Institutions would guarantee to repay 20% of grants to the Ministry of Finance introduces a powerful incentive for these self selected institutions to achieve their own internal efficiency and improves the sustainability of the reform elements of the project. 6.11 The Pilot Textbook Procurement Fund poses the risk that there might be limited demand from oblasts for loans to procure textbooks, given the stringent fiscal situation in Russia. Another risk,
 Russian Federation: Education Innovation Project Page 35 associated with the textbook related components of the project, is that the barriers to entry for new private publishers will remain too high, and the project will not succeed in promoting competition for school textbooks. Current high real interest rates are a potentially severe deterrent to private publishers, and some observers have argued that without interest subsidies, demonopolization of the textbook publishing industry will be limited. Others feel that this is too pessimistic, and that the development of clear and open mechanisms for establishing educational standards and evaluating and approving textbooks, grants to develop new titles and more efficient methods for disseminating information about textbook availability and ordering will be adequate. These components will be carefully monitored and evaluated. The pilot nature of the Textbook Fund component and the overall cautious scope of the project will provide important lessons for future Bank projects in the education sector in Russia.

Since 1990 the Russian higher education system has been rapidly changing. A lot of progress in reforming the system has been achieved both at the governmental and the grass-root levels. Many innovations and initiatives have been undertaken to meet the challenges of the transition from centrally- planned economy and authoritarian society to the market economy system and democratic political system. At the same time the reports show that at the moment the higher education is characterized by many imbalances, distortions and imperfections, which are partly inherited from the old system, partly reflect transitional processes. The main issues identified are: a. Structural-functional imbalances & distortions. Underdevelopment of social sciences still persist which influences the whole educational system. In many HEIs education is oriented towards excessive specialization. Focus on inputs (number of staff, formal qualifications of staff, length of courses and the hours a student spends on each course etc.) rather than outputs is still dominating. Standards are frequently equated with initial amount rather than final quality and the search for more efficient and effective methods of teaching is inhibited. Responses of HEls to the market demand for educational services and particular types of human capital bears short-term character. In the absence of the long-term strategy on the governmental level this leads to the new structural-functional distortions, reflected in the professional structure of enrolment, contents of education and curriculum. b. Imbalances in centralization/autonomy proportions. HEIs have little real autonomy over the use of budgetary funding, but at the same time there is no real accountability for funding from other sources. They are constrained by norms and standards relating to aspects such as staff-students ratios, teaching loads, etc. At the same time HEIs obtained an extremely high degree of academic autonomy with insufficient guidance of the contents of education, curriculum, etc., either on the side of the Government, or of the academic community. c. Imbalanced relationship between administrative and academic responsibilities and decision-making power within HEIs, accompanied by ineffective management system. Academics have little decision-making power over the allocation of resources. In reality this is under complete and unchallenged control of senior management. Administrative decisions very rarely become subject of revision or approval by autonomous stake-holders of HEIs. Quite often trivial decisions are taken at very high levels. This results in slowness of decision-making and, perhaps more serious, a split between the decision and its impact. Formal decision-making responsibility is in the hands of a relatively few number of people. Most of the staff in Russian HEIs seem to have little real power to make decisions and, as a consequence, bear little responsibility.
 Page 42 Annex A d. Imbalances of public/private elements in the system of HE. Introduction of commercialized elements in HE (connected with short-term orientation on current demand for educational services and new human capital) undermines public roots of HE, leads to unnecessary neglect of fundamental education and general knowledge. Also this preserves low level of public accountability and transparency, opposes participation of non-university members in HEIs governance. HEIs are drifting toward being profit- making centers instead of a non-profit providers of the educational services. This is worsened by the absence of clearly specified property rights (laws, charters, rules), which opens a possibility to "spontaneous privatization" of the public HEIs. THE DIRECTION OF REFORM 13. The reports imply, therefore, that the WB project should support institutional changes which would lead to the reform of the system. These reforms are expected to, inter alia, contribute to: a. elimination of structural-functional imbalances, particularly by improvement of the quality of education in social sciences with special emphasis on the educational outputs; b. correction of centralization/autonomy imbalances; support of the prospective initiatives and innovations in HE at the grass-root level; development of academic co-ordination and monitoring of the quality of education; C. development of the separation of administrative and academic responsibilities; improvement of the system of management; d. increase of various stake-holders' involvement in the governance of HEIs; increase of accountability and transparency of HEIs management. The following description of the current situation in Russian textbook creation and supply is based on a series of studies which were carried out under the Project (the analysis of textbook procurement funding in 26 Regions, availability of textbooks in 8 Regions, analysis of the composition and formation process of the Federal list of textbooks etc.). Discussion of preliminary results at a representative conference in Golytsino (November 1995), at a seminar for the heads of Regional Education Authorities (Kaliningrad, February 1996), as well as meetings with selected education system workers, publishers and experts have made it possible to draw an accurate picture of the current situation in textbook creation and supply in Russia. Availability of Textbooks in Second Cycle Schools 2. A selective survey of the availability of textbooks in schools in various regions in Russia has shown that schools are generally well-provided with the necessary number of textbooks with the exception of certain individual disciplines (e.g., foreign languages). Despite this there are immediately underlying factors presenting very serious threats to the quality of education offered to Russian children in the public education system. 3. A systemic undersupply of "Federal List" textbooks ordered by schools over the past three years has resulted in a drastic increase in the average Me of textbooks which is now approaching the upper limit of permitted and feasible use. Stocks are old and are now rapidly depleting. The implication is that in the next one or two years textbooks will need replacing on a much heavier scale than at the old optimum annual rate of 25 per cent. Further, the technical characteristics (especially binding) of some recently published textbooks prohibit use for the full four year period. Such new textbooks are bound to "paperback" standards, glued rather than sewn, thus reducing classroom durability and adding to textbook needs. 4. The need for a large scale replacement of textbooks is determined by qualitative as well as quantitative factors. The content of some textbooks included in the Federal List is not consistent with modern methodological requirements. This applies not only to human and social sciences. There are many cases when there is a lack of continuity between different textbooks within a single course of study and between courses. Many textbooks published over the past few years are not supported by the necessary teachers', supplementary and resource books. Most textbooks are poorly illustrated and the quality of printing is far below that of established foreign textbook systems. This is underlined by the conclusions of the Project's analysis of the Federal list and with the results of an opinion poll conducted among teachers in various regions. These findings underline the need for greater choice and for more coordinated publishing and evaluation programs. 5. Research indicates a current requirement for new textbooks, new editions and reprints of available textbooks at over 300 million units, at least double the "normal" annual need for textbook renewal. The cost of materials and printing alone, of such a number, is of the order of $400 - 500 million at current
 Page 66 Annex B prices excluding new textbook creation and promotion costs. Funding Textbook Provision for Second Cycle Schools 6. The MGPE estimates the optimum requirement for the Federal List of textbooks for schools in the 1996/7 academic year at approximately R 1.5 trillion ($300 million). The differential between this figure and that above is the result of conceptual difference - the Ministry is concerned only to replace redundant stock while the total figure includes replacement of inappropriate, unsatisfactory and badly produced titles. 7. Textbook procurement will now be funded from the budgets of the Regional Education Authorities. The Federal budget for 1996 includes R 500 billion ($100 million) of financial assistance to the Regions for these purposes, which has been confirmed by Government Resolution. The fundamental change in 1996 was that funds were provided directly to the Regions instead of the old practice of channeling the budgetary loan (provided to the Regions) through the MGPE for the payment of the centralized order. The new procedure makes it possible for any Region to order textbooks directly or on a centralized basis through the MGPE if it finds this arrangement convenient and transfers the funds to the MGPE. 8. Regions raise funds variously, but primarily from their own budgets, debiting respective amounts to Rayon budgets. In 1995, the ratio of Regions' own resources to loans from the Federal budget was 1:1. In 1996, the ratio was weighted heavily towards Regional budgets. 9. Other financial sources are few. Contributions from sponsors and parents are difficult to estimate because they are not centralized (contributions from parents are accumulated and remain at the school level). Surveys indicate that from 20 to 40 per cent of parents could afford to pay for the set of textbooks and individual regions (Kabardino-Balkaria for one) make successful use of this source. Loan schemes for parents (where textbooks are lent for a small charge) or buy-back from parents at the end of the academic year are not practiced. 10. Sponsor contributions from international charity organizations, primarily the Soros Foundation, are used to develop new textbooks rather than procure textbooks for schools. Most, perhaps the majority, of recently published new textbooks have been created with the financial support of the Soros Foundation. Institutional and Economic Description of the Textbook Publishing Sector 11. As with nearly all Central and Eastern European countries Russia is in the early and most traumatic stage of the transition from a centralized education and textbook supply system. The main characteristics are: * A switch from a single-source to multichannel (central, regional, local, parents and sponsors) financing of textbook procurement and delivery. Financing is already transferred from the MGPE; * Development of decentralized ways of ordering textbooks. Direct contractual relations between regions and publishing houses are gradually replacing the system of centralized orders implemented by the MGPE;
 Russian Federation: Education Innovation Project Page 67 * An increase in the choice of textbooks and education programs; * Reduction of the textbook monopoly held by PROSVESCHENIYE and rapid reduction in dependence on the State distribution monopoly of ROSKNIGA (with real and potential cost benefits). There is a growing number of independent publishers. However, with one exception, they still provide only a small percentage of the Federal list of textbooks. The State of the Educational Book Market 12. The textbook publishing sector has been substantially liberalized over the past few years as follows: participation of independent publishers in the Federal List; availability of a choice within the Federal List; multichannel funding; opportunities to sign direct contracts with publishers instead of the system of centralized orders through the MGPE; open market prices for textbooks available in the marketplace. As a result of general economic and MGPE reforms textbook publishing has become substantially market-oriented. 13. At the same time the education book (and related materials) market is still only at a formative stage. The education market remains restricted, first of all, by the financial frailty of most of its major participants (neither publisher nor customer have sufficient financial resources to ensure regular and stable delivery of textbooks to schools), and secondly, by the lack of a well-developed market information infrastructure permitting the consumer to access up-to-date information on textbooks published or in preparation ,thus permitting the adequate consumer choice. 14. The majority of education publishers are recently established with inadequate working capital for the production of very large printings of textbooks. This is a particular problem for Russia in comparison with East and Central Europe. Russia has a school population in excess of the total population of any of those countries except Poland. 15. High interest rates and low levels of collateral make the financing of the massive printings of books in the Federal list especially daunting. Unless this is redressed there will remain a serious threat of either continued monopoly or a proliferation of smaller regional publishers working on smaller printings. In either case choice and quality standards will suffer in the medium term. Currently prepayment covering the cost of paper and printing is the only way for publishing houses to produce long print runs. Lack of funding resources in the Regions and the stressed financial position of most publishing houses, arrears of payment and the need to maintain low prices do not permit publishers to earn the added value necessary to build up working capital and to effectively promote their textbooks on the market. 16. What is now by far the largest customer group, the Regional Education Authorities, also has problems of resourcing and timing the funding for textbooks. Some, in the Moscow and Petersburg Regions for example, are well funded, others are not. Funds for the procurement of textbooks are not, in most cases, allocated on a systematic basis. In the absence of a clear regulatory framework defining responsibilities and specifying the financial source for the provision of textbooks to schools, regional administrations sometimes wait for subsidies and centralized loans from the Federal Budget before allocating funds for textbooks from their own budgets. Given the seasonal nature of the textbook market and the production cycle that implies (particularly if prepayment must be made) the present system does not guarantee sustainable provision of textbooks. There is some evidence that at least some regions are aware of this and are taking measures which may partially redress this situation.
 Page 68 Annex B 17. The financial weakness of all the major market participants (publishers, printers, Regions and schools) makes it very difficult to develop an infrastructure capable of furnishing the consumer with the required information on the availability of existing and forthcoming textbooks. The increasing variety of textbooks and methodological approaches and the opportunity for informed selection have created demand for much more information on which to base orders for textbooks. Information on price, terms of delivery and payment, series continuity, teachers', supplementary and resource materials etc. all needs to be available in a consolidated and accessible form. The Role of the Federal Authorities in Managing the Development of the Textbook Publishing System 18. The transformation of the textbook publishing system is not a controlled process. The MGPE has neither the resources nor the leverage necessary to manage educational materials development or quality control: * There is no legislative framework ensuring that schools use books consistent with approved programs and required technical standards. Publishers entering the market rarely have experience of publishing textbooks for schools incorporating these requirements. Roskompechat and (theoretically) the Bureau of Sanitary Epidemiological Surveillance are nominally responsible for maintenance of standards but there is no legislative framework for such monitoring. Neither the Federal Expert Council, charged with maintenance of textbook standards, nor the MGPE has clear authority to do this. Under the Law on Education teachers are free to select education literature for teaching his/her subject. Even the Federal list can be imposed only through central purchase or the traditional respect in which it is held. * A methodological framework is not in place. Neither National Education Standards nor testing systems have been applied. The procedure for the creation and updating of the Federal List is insufficiently transparent and objective. The Federal list is not an integrated system, but merely an order form for the centralized supply of textbooks to be supplied in the current the year. The compilation of the Federal list is unsystematic. The Federal Expert Council does not have an objective basis for selecting textbooks (National Education Standards) and makes recommendations to approve (or disapprove) textbooks without clear connection to the whole education literature package in a given discipline. Nor does it apply consistent criteria or numeric scoring to ensure objectivity and comparability or evaluate design and production quality and price. It is common for a teacher who starts using a new textbook to find no consistent follow-up textbook for the next academic year encouraging conservative choice of well-tried but outdated materials with consequent constraint on educational development; * There is no sustainable financial basis for resolving these problems. If the responsibility for improving the quality of educational materials is vested in the Federal Authorities then the federal budget must have provisions for the effective formation of the Federal List, including preparation of innovative textbook programs, the issue and testing of pilot and trial editions, retraining of teachers and so on. Such funds are not available. Implications and Dangers 19. On the basis of the above analysis it can be seen that without the legal, institutional and financial means to enable the Federal Government to influence development of a market based educational materials supply sector there are numerous potentially negative implications.
 Russian Federation: Education Innovation Project Page 69 * Potential deterioration of the quality of education and of the common education space as schools turn to "local" or cheaper low-quality textbooks inconsistent Federal education and hygienic standards; * Deterioration of the quality of textbooks and course materials. Retention of out-dated and inferior materials in the absence of tested, innovative new materials; * Intensification of uncontrolled blackmarket trends in the textbook publishing sector (piracy, spurious recommendations, hijacking of authors and other typical negative features of uncontrolled change); * Lowering of standards of production and design and of durability. Use of inappropriate materials and printing machinery. Eventual increase in total system cost and adverse effect on children's wellbeing; * Inability to achieve National Education Standards on a consistent, nationwide base due to poor textbooks; * Encouragement of diverse and centrifugal curricula and textbook content undermining the high common standards of school education; a Continuation of the central monopoly because only one real competitor to the State Publishing House has emerged Summary Conclusions and Recommendations 20. In order to speed up the reform of the textbook publishing sector, improve the quality of education and avert the dangerous consequences of uncontrolled transition processes it is necessary to: * Strengthen and improve the role of the Federal authorities in the process of directing the development of market based textbook publishing as a common national resource center ensuring the development of the methodological basis of education, improvements in textbook quality, the awareness of national standards and compliance with these; * Create improved economic conditions for the operation and development of the textbook publishing market by facilitating the formation of market infrastructures and strengthening major participants; * Take urgent steps to ensure mass replacement of worn-out and/or outdated textbooks. 21. Additional expenditure from the Federal and Regional budgets will be required during the transition period that will permit: * Establishment of a market information infrastructure; * Renewal of the content of education by developing and publishing textbooks consistent with contemporary requirements;

The proposed Education Innovation Project would have a component which would be a modest step in addressing the complexities of supply and demand in the textbook market in Russia. The School Textbook Reform Component would improve the quality and supply of textbooks through: the provision of electronic information and book ordering systems; training and equipment for both the MGPE and regional educational administrations. The project would, in addition, strengthen educational standards and create new textbook titles; and equity of access to timely information on new and improved textbooks throughout the RF for schools, parents and students. Specific Project Tasks * To establish a logical system of authority, responsibility and accountability of, respectively, the Federal and Regional Education Authorities concerning the choice, purchase and supply of textbooks and other educational literature for secondary schools; * To establish a system for textbook quality monitoring including Federal list renewal and replacement and extension consistent with increased choice of books and other educational options; * To establish a nationwide market information infrastructure that would ensure directed and rational decision-making in textbook ordering together with real time interaction between customers and producers. * To train education managers and practitioners in the use of the textbook ordering and information system. Subcomponent One: Textbook Quality Improvement 23. The improvement and development of the system of National Education Standards is a key Subproject whose principal task in the context of general textbook reform is to establish a basis for a consistent development of the education content, an objective system of textbook quality assurance and a purposeful updating and extension of the Federal list of Textbooks. 24. The subcomponent aims to further the work on Standards already initiated by the Russian Government. It is directed towards the solution of: (a) the key conceptual issues; and (b) the experimental trialling of major mechanisms to establish, put in place and periodically review and update national educational standards and the examinations/tests related to them. The subcomponent is expected to provide a plan for the establishment and institutional framework for a nationally acceptable system of standards and tests. 25. The project would analyze the current status of the National System of Standards and Tests and would formulate ways to improve and develop the National System of Standards and related Tests. Based on international experience, it would help to prepare and pilot models for standards and associated tests for selected disciplines and education levels. The project would also seek to identify user requirements
 Russian Federation: Education Innovation Project Page 71 in for both secondary and higher education products, as well as the requirements of education literature creators (authors, publishers) of the system of standards and tests. Procedures for the development, approval and periodic updating of the system of standards and tests would be developed. 26. The other part of this subcomponent would address the evaluation and validation of textbooks and other educational materials through the managerial and technical reform of the Federal Expert Council. This reform would focus on the development of revised functions for the Federal Expert Council which would create a more effective and nationally respected and understood Approved list. This Approved List would, in turn, provide the basis for the Federal List and, eventually, become the only list from which schools could obtain guidance in choosing their textbooks. It is assumed that the Federal Expert Council would resume its developmental role in textbook and curriculum innovation; and that the Council and the Ministry of General and Professional Education would have complementary functions in the creation and dissemination of information on textbooks approval and the structure and use of the Approved List. 27. The project would address the restructuring of the Council to include: the introduction of a Board of Management with improved operational methods and equipment; the revision and enhancement of the evaluation methods of the Council to ensure more transparent, objective and comparable standards of evaluation;the introduction of specific procedures for the selection of evaluators; the introduction of numerically based weighted criteria for evaluation; the evaluation of design and production standards and of prices; and substantial training in all these areas; Subcomponent Two: Renewal of the Federal List 28. The analysis of textbooks recommended by the Ministry of General and professional Education (the Federal list of Textbooks) will permit identification of courses and subjects which lack textbooks and/or are in need of renewal. It will also provide for the revision of the Federal list of Textbooks with potential to exclude those textbooks which are outdated and do not correspond to modern requirements, textbooks which are not supported by the requisite methodological and supplementary materials, textbooks which prevent the development of methodologically integrated curricula on given subjects, and of textbooks which are not coordinated with the other textbooks at the same levels. 29. In addition to the main objective, the analysis of the Federal list of Textbooks will also facilitate certain functions in terms of the project implementation as a whole. First, the analysis is intended to identify a list of textbooks which are in the greatest need of being replaced, and of subjects which need a more varied choice of textbooks within the limits of the Federal list. These lists will be used in the process of a competition to develop new educational literature. Second, in the course of the analysis, a methodology will be tested for a comprehensive evaluation of textbooks with a potential for subsequent use in practical activities of the Federal Expert Council. 30.  Page 78 AnnexC RUSSLAN FEDERATION Education Innovation Project ANNEX C PILOT TEXTBOOK PROCUREMENT FUND Textbook Publishing - Background 1. The decision that the Federal Budget would no longer finance centralized procurement of textbook publishing and a gradual devolution of funding responsibilities to the regional level has brought about institutional changes in the purchasing and financing of new textbooks for secondary schools. The MGPE previously selected books to be published and distributed to schools, based upon the aggregation of orders from school systems nation-wide, and organized the publication of these books by placing direct orders to particular publishing houses. This system led to a lag of two years between the selection of texts at the school level and the delivery of textbooks. Today, regions have assumed responsibility for selecting and paying for secondary school textbooks and they now select titles and place orders for these texts directly with publishers. While the time gap between ordering and delivery has been reduced, there remain several serious impediments to both textbook updating and the development of a competitive publishing industry. These include (inter alia) barriers to entry of new publishers and a general lack of incentives to develop, publish and purchase new textbooks. Issues Textbook Supply 2. Prosveschenie Publishing House, a state-owned company which published 100% of education literature for secondary schools before 1993, still holds a near-monopoly in the Russian textbook publishing market. Moreover, now that public control over textbook publishing is reduced, the underdeveloped market allows Prosveschenie to issue outdated education literature rather than new books which would incur additional costs in order to comply with international standards and stricter requirements concerning textbook printing design. The ability of Prosveschenie to issue old textbooks, for which it has sole copyright, at relatively low prices still gives it substantial market power . This situation deters the development of new textbooks and therefore inhibits curriculum reform. 3. Some regions have sought to break this monopoly by directing business to a new single publisher at the local or oblast level so as to capture the local education literature market with a local company. Often these companies are interested only in gaining a foothold in the market not in improving textbook quality or in developing new textbooks; therefore they prefer to "buy over" authors of existing textbooks. 4. On a national level, one large private publishing house has begun to compete with Prosveschnie. These two houses together dominate the market and own the copyrights for about 90 % of all textbooks included in the Federal Set. The other 10% are published by small independent firms specializing in education literature. The success of these publishers in issuing high-quality textbooks at relatively low prices indicates the possibility of change but a much greater effort is necessary to bring about sustainable reform.
 Russian Federation: Education Innovation Project Page 79 Lack of Working Capital for Publishers 5. The development of competition is impeded by the financial inability of new independent publishers to publish mass print-runs of their textbooks, since the time gap between the payment of materials and printing costs (which constitute 80% of the textbook cost) and payments by customers is at least 4-6 months. Moreover, many regions do not pay promptly. These publishers find it difficult to borrow working capital. Interest rates are generally in excess of 48 % in rubles or about 25% in hard currency while inflation was approximately 22% in 1996. Even at these rates, publishers face difficulty in obtaining loans due to: (i) a lack of assets which could be used as security for loans taken to issue a mass print-run; (ii) delays in customers' payments, particularly where the customer is a regional administration; and (iii) a lack of interest by the banking sector in financing Russian enterprises in general due to more favorable opportunities, at least until recently, to earn high rates of return buying government securities. The reduction of the bank interest rate for commercial loans that is expected in the coming year due to the greater macroeconomic stabilization and the opening up of the government debt market to foreigners, may help somewhat. However, access of small publishers to loans would still be limited by their lack of assets for collateral. Demand for Textbooks 6. Regions are also constrained in the purchase of new textbook titles by a general lack of finance. Even when federal funds have been made available for textbooks, anecdotal evidence suggests that such funds are used for other purposes such as salary payments to teachers. Less than half of the funds allocated to the regions were actually transferred to publishers as payments for textbooks. No mechanism exists which could guarantee a "fair" distribution of the funds between the regions. Summary 7. While the prerequisites for establishing a competitive textbook market (education liberalization, an opportunity for users to select textbooks and programs, transition to direct relations between customers and producers, etc.) are theoretically in place, the market is actually split between two companies. This situation inhibits textbook updating (and, hence, curricular reform), restricts choice, has a detrimental effect on the quality of printing design and threatens unwarranted price increases for textbooks.
